definition[0]: to have a bad effect on something so that it is no longer attractive, enjoyable, useful etc
example[0]: The whole park is spoiled by litter.
example[1]: We didn’t let the incident spoil our day.
example[2]: I don’t want to spoil your fun.
example[3]: Why do you always have to spoil everything?
definition[1]: to give a child everything they want, or let them do whatever they want, often with the result that they behave badly
example[4]: She’s an only child, but they didn’t really spoil her.
example[5]: His mother and sisters spoil him rotten (=spoil him very much).
definition[2]: to look after someone in a way that is very kind or too kind
example[6]: You’ll have to let me spoil you on your birthday.
example[7]: Go on, spoil yourself. Have another piece of cake.
example[8]: Food will spoil if the temperature in your freezer rises above 8°C.
definition[4]: to mark a ballot paper wrongly so that your vote is not included
definition[5]: to have a bad effect on something so that it is much less attractive, enjoyable etc
example[9]: New housing developments are spoiling the countryside.
example[10]: The bad weather completely spoiled our holiday.
definition[6]: to spoil something completely and permanently
example[11]: Using harsh soap to wash your face can ruin your skin.
example[12]: The argument ruined the evening for me.
definition[7]: to spoil something by making it less attractive or enjoyable
example[13]: His handsome Arab features were marred by a long scar across his face.
example[14]: Outbreaks of fighting marred the New Year celebrations.
definition[8]: to slightly spoil something that is generally very good, beautiful, or impressive
example[15]: The huge number of tourists rather detracts from the city’s appeal.
example[16]: There were a few minor irritations, but this did not detract from our enjoyment of the holiday.
definition[9]: to spoil something that you have been trying to achieve
example[17]: The bombings undermined several months of careful negotiations.
definition[10]: to spoil a friendly relationship between people or countries
example[18]: The affair has soured relations between the UK and Russia.
definition[11]: to spoil a close relationship completely, so that people can no longer trust each other
example[19]: Their marriage was poisoned by a terrible dark secret.
definition[12]: to spoil something important or something that has been carefully planned
example[20]: If there’s any delay, it will mess up our whole schedule.
definition[13]: waste material such as earth and stones from a mine or hole in the ground
